Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Manufacturing through Applied STEM Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Collaborating with rural secondary schools, representatives from the manufacturing industry, and a learning technology company, Chippewa Valley Technical College (CVTC) is developing a Mobile Simulation Laboratory and associated curricula to bring advanced manufacturing equipment and simulation technologies directly to high school teachers and students. Curricula are broken down into four modules: Machining, Welding, Automation, and STEM in Manufacturing. High school teachers are working alongside CVTC faculty to team-teach the Mobile Simulation Laboratory modules. Students completing the modules receive college credit and are encouraged to matriculate into postsecondary manufacturing programs. The regional manufacturing industry support the project in an advisory capacity, informing curricula and interacting directly with high school students through guest speaking events and company/plant tours. A week-long professional development workshop at CVTC will be held for high school teachers prior to the Mobile Simulation Laboratory's launch. The goal of the project is to expand STEM education opportunities, particularly advance manufacturing education to rural, underserved areas.

The project increases interest in advanced manufacturing among high school students which leads to increased enrollments at postsecondary manufacturing programs. Through rigorous evaluation and dissemination of project results, combined with targeted rural outreach and professional development, the project contributes to the economic development of the northwestern region of Wisconsin by addressing the need for more qualified technicians in advanced manufacturing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Advancing Manufacturing through Applied STEM Education (AMASE) project sought to expand Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM) opportunities for High School students, and prepare technicians for manufacturing and engineering careers through simulation technology and applied education while increasing the capacity of rural secondary teachers to provide advanced manufacturing education. A Mobile Manufacturing Laboratory was designed, built, and sent to four participating rural high schools to enhance technology students’ educational experiences.

The project was proposed and carried out to address a regional need in Northwestern Wisconsin for expanded training in automation, process improvement, productivity, and quality to meet the demands required for a more educated and skilled workforce. Local graduates of manufacturing programs must be prepared for a highly technical career. Regional employers voiced their need for technicians with advanced technical skills and the hands-on experience necessary for immediate entry into open positions, along with a need for these same employees to be trained and skilled in highly complex technologies and processes. Manufacturers desired employees with advanced math and science skills, along with more critical thinking and problem-solving capabilities. Unfortunately, many of the rural High Schools that serve these areas were underequipped and not fully capable to handle the expanded needs for a prepared workforce.

Over the duration of the project headed by Chippewa Valley Technical College (CVTC), machining, welding, automation, and applied STEM curriculum was developed and delivered to the partner high schools to help address the identified skills gap. Equipment, training, and hands-on educational opportunities that would likely otherwise not be available to these rural High Schools were made available to Technology students. Students at these schools were tested before and after their experiences with the Mobile Laboratory. Thirty-eight students gained industry-recognized credentials in at least one of the focus areas through their experiences with the Mobile Laboratory, and the majority of those students also earned college credit(s) for their efforts. Additionally, the students gained exposure to areas of advanced manufacturing that would have been otherwise unavailable to them.

Technology Instructors at every one of the partner high schools, along with instructors from other rural high schools in Western Wisconsin received professional development in machining, welding, automation, and applied STEM. Beyond the duration of the AMASE project, this training will enable continued exposure and development in advanced manufacturing for technology students from the partner high schools.

The number of rural and underserved high school students enrolled in manufacturing programs at CVTC increased dramatically throughout the duration of the project. The measurable impact of the project, in terms of rural students enrolling into CVTC manufacturing programs, grew each year as more High School students closer to graduation were exposed to higher-level learning opportunities as part of their Mobile Laboratory experience.
